text.Phoenix: ... * huff * ... * huff * ... Grr!! How did I get into this mess...?

text.ACTION: That's far enough! You can't run forever, Mr. Phoenix Wright!

text.Phoenix: Wha...!? What have I done wrong!?

text.ACTION: I cannot allow you to go on like this!

text.Phoenix: ...? B-But I'm just a simple defense attorney!

text.ACTION: Silence! You are no longer worthy of your title.
September 8, 9:08 AM District Court Defendant Lobby No. 1

text.Phoenix: What a nightmare... And I bet it was this ringtone that caused it... I really shouldn't be dozing off right before a trial starts anyway...
Huh... looks like they hung up.

text.???: Ah, good. I finally found it. Talk about a close call. I hate to do this to you, but... It's nothing personal... Mr. Attorney.

text.ACTION: A few minutes later... District Court Defendant Lobby No. 1

text.Phoenix: ... Ouch... My head... It's throbbing... And why does it feel... so foggy in there...?

text.???: Gooood morning!

text.Phoenix: Ack! Uh... G-Good morning...

text.???: What's wrong!? You don't look well! People are at their best first thing in the morning! Where's that fighting spirit!?

text.Phoenix: ... Sorry, but can you please turn the cheeriness down? My head... sort of hurts...

text.???: Roger that!

text.Phoenix: ... Um... Am I in trouble or something?

text.???: Huh? "Trouble...?"

text.Phoenix: W-Wait, never mind. You're a policewoman, right? I thought maybe I had done something wrong...?

text.???: Wh-What are you talking about? I'm the one in trouble!

text.Phoenix: ... What?

text.Byrde: I'm placing my life in your hands today, Mr. Phoenix Wright!

text.Phoenix: Life... in... my hands...?

text.Byrde: You promised me! You said you would prove that I was not guilty !

text.Phoenix: "N... Not... guilty"?

text.Byrde: Just when I thought all hope was lost; when all the other lawyers had laughed me off... "Leave it to me!" you said! You! The one and only Phoenix Wright came to save the day! And just like that, I was moved to tears, sir! I'll never forget what you're doing for me, EVER!

text.Phoenix: ( What is this girl babbling about...? )

text.Byrde: Actually, I really love to watch court proceedings, and I always root for you to win! When I'm off duty, I like to come here and... ...? What's wrong? You've been acting really strange and you keep staring at me. You're making me kind of nervous, sir...

text.Phoenix: Oh... sorry. ( Hmm... I'm afraid to ask, but here goes... ) So, this might sound bad, but... uh... Who are you...?

text.Byrde: Whaaaaat!? Mr. Wright!! How can you say that!? How can you do this to the fragile heart of a girl about to go on trial...? You're absolutely horrible!

text.Phoenix: No -- I mean, I didn't mean it like that!

text.Byrde: Is this how a defense attorney treats his clients, sir!? I can't believe this!!

text.Phoenix: No, it's just... ...Well, I think you have the wrong person. I'm...
... ... I'm... Who am I? ( Why am I drawing a blank...? )

text.Bailiff: The trial will begin shortly. Will the defendant and her lawyer please proceed to the courtroom immediately!

text.Byrde: The trial's about to start! I'm counting on you in there, OK?

text.Phoenix: ( Hmm... I guess I must have amnesia ... Let's see... What can I piece together...? Hmm, from our conversation, I can safely say that I'm probably a defense attorney . And that girl... I said I'd prove her " not guilty "... I can't believe I made such an irresponsible promise. ) Aaaaaargh! Someone, please!! Tell me this is just a bad dream!

text.ACTION: September 8, 10:00 AM District Court Courtroom No. 2

text.Judge: Court is now in session for the trial of Maggey Byrde.

text.Payne: The prosecution is ready, Your Honor.

text.Judge: What is it, Mr. Wright?

text.Phoenix: Um, er... Are you talking to me...?

text.Judge: Do you see any other defense attorneys here?

text.Phoenix: ( I guess not. )
text._info: (Changed from [I guess not. Urk.] in the original release)

text.Judge: Now then, are you ready?

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( I guess I should say, "Yes" for now. )

CHOICE.Judge: Are you ready, Mr. Wright?

CHOICE.Phoenix: Yes, Your Honor. ( ... Wait a sec... If her life is in my hands... I should really do the responsible thing... )

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads to "Actually, you see, Your Honor... My memory is kind of..."

CHOICE.Phoenix: Um... What if I said, "No"? Would that be alright?

CHOICE.Judge: Of course it wouldn't!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Then why bother asking to begin with?? )

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads to "Actually, you see, Your Honor... My memory is kind of..."

text.Phoenix: Actually, you see, Your Honor... My memory is kind of...

text.Judge: The court will not hear the defense's excuses. Because the defendant is a member of the police, this case is under great scrutiny. Therefore, we must make this trial fair but swift. I believe I have told you this before. I hope you're not telling me you've forgotten!

text.Phoenix: ( Actually, I have... )
text._info: (Changed from [Actually, I did...] in the original release)

text.Judge: Mr. Payne, your opening statement, please.

text.Payne: Yes, Your Honor. As I'm sure you're well aware, the defendant is accused of killing her lover . What's worse, her lover was a fellow police officer !

text.Phoenix: A policeman? You did WHAT to a policeman!?

text.Byrde: It wasn't me! And besides, Dustin and I... We weren't "lovers" like that!

text.Payne: In any case... The prosecution will prove that the guilty party is none other than the defendant!

text.Judge: Very well. Mr. Payne, please call your first witness.

text.Payne: Hee, hee, hee. It's been a while, Mr. Wright. Let's see what you've learned since last time. I won't show you any mercy this time, rookie!

text.Phoenix: Okaaay... ( And who are you again!? )

text.Payne: The prosecution calls Detective Dick Gumshoe to the stand.
text._info: (Changed from [Please bring Detective Dick Gumshoe to the stand.] in the original release)

text.Byrde: Here we go! Don't let me down, Mr. Wright!

text.Phoenix: ( Nowhere to hide... I'm sooo dead... )

text.Payne: Witness, please state your name and occupation.

text.Gumshoe: My name is Dick Gumshoe, sir. I'm the detective in charge of homicides down at the precinct, sir.

text.Judge: You don't look very well, Detective.

text.Gumshoe: Well, sir, the defendant... She works under me, so, you know...

text.Phoenix: You work under that detective?

text.Byrde: Yes, sir! And while I was a trainee, he was always watching out for me, sir! He's such a wonderful guy, sir! I'll never forget what he's done for me!

text.Phoenix: ( OK, calm down, I believe you. )

text.Payne: Detective Gumshoe. Please describe for us the details of this murder.

text.Gumshoe: Yes, sir. It happened at the park near headquarters, " Expos√© Park ". The victim was one of the local cops, Dustin Prince. He was pushed down from the benches on the upper path, sir. The landing beat his body up bad and snapped his neck.

text.Payne: The details are listed in the report that was distributed yesterday...

text.Judge: Ah, yes. This autopsy report , correct?

text.Phoenix: ( Why do I not remember getting a copy...? )

text.Judge: I see everything is in order here. Even the estimated time of death is unusually well documented!

text.Gumshoe: The victim's watch stopped from the impact of the landing, sir. The results of the autopsy confirmed the time of death.

text.Payne: If I may, Your Honor, the prosecution would like to submit this photograph.

text.Judge: Very well. The court accepts it into evidence.
Now then, I recall at yesterday's preliminary hearing, a very important piece of evidence was brought to our attention.

text.Payne: Yes, Your Honor.

text.Gumshoe: Yes, sir.

text.Phoenix: Yes... I guess?

text.Judge: Mr. Wright! Is your head on right today!? There was a very crucial piece of evidence found under the victim's body!

text.Phoenix: Um, was there?

text.Byrde: Have you lost your mind!?

text.Phoenix: Well, actually... Um, it's just nerves. Give me a second.

text.Byrde: Whaaaat!? How can you talk like such an amateur!? I thought you were a pro, sir! ... Alright, sir. I'll help you through this! At a time like this, maybe you ought to take a glance at the Court Record !

text.Phoenix: ...Court Record?

text.Byrde: Yup! Info about evidence and people involved with this case are all listed there, sir! You can look a the Court Record by pressing [the R Button / Tab]!
text._info: (Changed from [You can look at the Court Record by touching the Court Record Button!] in the original release)

text.Phoenix: [The R Button / Tab], huh... You really know what you're talking about, don't you?
text._info: (Changed from [The Court Record Button...? You really know what you're talking about, huh?] in the original release)

text.Byrde: It's too bad I'm a cop, right? Just think! I could totally be a legal aide instead!

text.Judge: Mr. Wright.

text.Phoenix: Yes, Your Honor!

text.Judge: Court is in session. Save your chit-chat for later!

text.Phoenix: S-Sorry, Your Honor... ( Well, I guess I'd better check the Court Record , and see what I can find... What was it again? [The R Button / Tab]...? )
text._info: (Changed from [What was it again? The Court Record Button...?] in the original release)

text.Judge: Alright, Mr. Wright. Let's see if your notes are in order. What was the piece of evidence found underneath the victim's body?

CHOICE.Phoenix: Um... I'm pretty sure it was a wallet...

CHOICE.Payne: Objection!
This is a court of law! You can't just make wild guesses!

CHOICE.Judge: Agreed.

CHOICE.Byrde: They're right, Mr. Wright! You have to check the Court Record before you answer! If you don't, your client might end up with a guilty verdict!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( "Your client"? You do realize that's you, right? )

CHOICE.Judge: I will ask you one more time.

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads back to "What was the piece of evidence found underneath the victim's body?"
Leads to "That's simple, Your Honor. A broken pair of glasses."

CHOICE.Phoenix: If he's a cop, then I guess maybe a badge or something...

CHOICE.Payne: Objection!
Mr. Wright! Please stick to the facts of this case!

CHOICE.Phoenix: Objection!
He is a policeman, correct?

CHOICE.Payne: I don't think you understand the problem here.

CHOICE.Judge: I will not have an uninformed lawyer in my court.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Yes, Your Honor. ( Guess there's no fooling those two. )

CHOICE.Byrde: Please, for my sake, look at the Court Record, sir!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Uh, with [the R Button / Tab], right? )
CHOICE._info: (Changed from [Uh, it's the Court Record Button, right?] in the original release)

CHOICE.Judge: I will ask you one more time.

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads back to "What was the piece of evidence found underneath the victim's body?"

text.Phoenix: That's simple, Your Honor. A broken pair of glasses .

text.Judge: That's right.

text.Gumshoe: The victim grabbed the criminal's glasses as he was being shoved, sir, and held onto them as he fell.

text.Byrde: Hey! Why are you giving me the evil eye!?

text.Phoenix: Those glasses you're wearing...

text.Byrde: Nnnngh... Yes, this is my spare pair. But these glasses they found at the scene of the crime are not mine! I swear, sir!

text.Phoenix: You sure about that?

text.Byrde: Look, it was a coincidence that on that same day, I accidentally stepped on mine!

text.Phoenix: ( A "coincidence" she says... Urk... )

text.Payne: Eh hee hee hee hee hee hee! Your Honor. I have further evidence to present.

text.Judge: Oh? You have more?

text.Payne: And this evidence is very decisive.

text.Judge: Very well! Let's hear from our witness about this "evidence".

text.Gumshoe:
There's something even more incriminating than the glasses under the victim's body, sir. 
During his date, the victim was pushed from the bench area. 
But he managed to write the culprit's name on the ground where he landed. 
I don't like saying it, but it was clearly the defendant's name, "Maggie", sir. 
With this piece of evidence and the glasses, it's hard to say she's not the culprit.

text.Payne: This is a picture of the writing, Your Honor.

text.Judge: Why, this is...! Yes, I can see the name is clearly written here.

text.Payne: The prosecution would like to submit this picture.

text.Judge: Understood. The court accepts it into evidence.

text.Phoenix: As if the glasses alone didn't make you look suspicious, the victim even wrote your name clear as day on the ground!

text.Byrde: But, but, but, I already told you! Those glasses aren't mine!!

text.Phoenix: And how do you explain his dying message?

text.Byrde: ... It's a conspiracy! I'm not guilty, sir!

text.Judge: Mr. Wright, you may cross-examine the witness.

text.Phoenix: Cross-examine?

text.Byrde: This is it! I'm counting on you!

text.Phoenix: Sure... But what am I supposed to do?

text.Byrde: WHAT!? This isn't like you at all! Normally, this is the part where you get in the witnesses' faces!

text.Phoenix: Get in their faces and do what?

text.Byrde: I guess there's no way around it! OK, I'm going to lend you a hand! The prosecution's witnesses all hide things from the court, which means they lie from time to time.

text.Phoenix: Lie? But... isn't that detective your superior?

text.Byrde: Well, even if they don't mean to lie, sometimes people just remember things wrong .

text.Phoenix: Hmm, like that detective. He does sort of look like a scatterbrain...

text.Byrde: It doesn't matter! Either way, it's bad for us, sir! That's why when you question witnesses, you have to find and expose their lies !

text.Judge: Mr. Wright. Your cross-examination, please.

text.Phoenix: Y-Yes, Your Honor. ( Talk about trial by fire. Here goes nothing. As long as I can " expose the lies ", we should be alright. )

text.Gumshoe: There's something even more incriminating than the glasses under the victim's body, sir.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Hmm, about those glasses... Do you have any proof that those belong to my client?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: The lenses are for near-sightedness, and are almost the same strength as hers. Even the frames look kinda like the ones she's wearing in her ID, pal.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Hmm... ( What should I do now? )
HOLD IT!
"Almost" and "kinda" are not good enough in a case like this!

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Er, um...

CHOICE.Phoenix: Do you have more definitive proof? Is there something that clearly links the defendant with those glasses!?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Er, um, uh... The dirt and sand rubbed out any traces of fingerprints or anything else.

CHOICE.Phoenix: So what you are saying, detective, is that you have nothing that proves those glasses are my client's.

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Um, something like that...

CHOICE.Payne: Wh-Wh-What!?

CHOICE.Judge: I see... Hmm... So there is no proof...

CHOICE.Byrde: Wow, that was amazing! I could totally feel it, down in my gut!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( We're in real trouble if those glasses really are hers... It's probably better to back out while we can. )

CHOICE.Byrde: Argh... Why don't you believe me...?

text.Gumshoe: During his date, the victim was pushed from the bench area.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Now, you're sure he was pushed and that's how he fell?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yeah, pal. If you look at the wounds on the victim's body, there's no way it was anything else.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Hmm...

CHOICE.Judge: Please continue with your testimony, detective.

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Anyway, the victim fell pretty far...

text.Gumshoe: But he managed to write the culprit's name on the ground where he landed.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
The culprit's name?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yeah. I was surprised, too. I didn't want to believe it, but...

CHOICE.Phoenix: Was the name that of my client?

CHOICE.ACTION: USER SELECTS Present Maggey Byrde profile

CHOICE.Phoenix: Objection!

text.Gumshoe: I don't like saying it, but it was clearly the defendant's name, "Maggie", sir.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Are you absolutely certain!?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Sorry, pal, but that's what it said. This is a picture of it. No matter which way you look, it still says "Maggie".

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Hmm... He's got a point... )
Huh?

CHOICE.Byrde: Don't "huh" me! I know the picture says "Maggie", but...

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Now that she mentions it, something does feel kind of off about this picture... )

CHOICE.Byrde: That's how you know you found a contradiction ! Now hurry up and present some evidence!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( So THAT'S what spotting a contradiction feels like... I'd better check the Court Record again... )

CHOICE.ACTION: USER SELECTS Present Maggey Byrde profile

CHOICE.Phoenix: Objection!

text.Gumshoe: With this piece of evidence and the glasses, it's hard to say she's not the culprit.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
And you are certain that it was the victim who wrote the name on the ground?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: There were scratches on his fingers from the rough sand, and there were grains of sand stuck under his pointer finger nail.

CHOICE.Judge: Hmm... It certainly seems that the name was written by the victim himself.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( That didn't go well. If it really was him, then we're in a lot of trouble... )

CHOICE.ACTION: USER SELECTS Present Maggey Byrde profile

CHOICE.Phoenix: Objection!

text.Byrde: Don't give up! Keep that fighting spirit going!

text.Phoenix: I'm glad you're all pumped up, but...

text.Byrde: I really want to see your " special move ", sir!

text.Phoenix: My what??

text.Byrde: You always look so cool when you present evidence!

text.Phoenix: Present ... evidence?

CHOICE.ACTION: USER SELECTS Oh, THAT present evidence!

CHOICE.Phoenix: Actually, I was just thinking about that!

CHOICE.Byrde: Yes! The great Phoenix Wright is back! Oh, that's right.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Huh?

CHOICE.Byrde: I heard that lately, you can present not only evidence , but people's profiles as well! It sure makes things a bit more complicated, so be careful, sir!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( People's profiles , huh? Alright, let's give this another try. )
Um, about this " presenting evidence "...

CHOICE.Byrde: OK. When you're listening to testimony , you can compare, it with the Court Record . If you do that, you're sure to find contradictions in the witness's statements!

CHOICE.Phoenix: C-Contradictions ?

CHOICE.Byrde: Well, there are many reasons why a testimony might contradict the evidence. The witness might be lying , or maybe they're just mistaken .

CHOICE.Phoenix: Uh huh. And?

CHOICE.Byrde: You still have no idea what I'm talking about?? When you find a contradiction , open the Court Record to the item you need...

CHOICE.Phoenix: And then I present that evidence, right!?

CHOICE.Byrde: You got it! You can also present people's profiles as evidence! With so many items, make sure you present the right thing!

CHOICE.Phoenix: Hmm... Sounds complicated, but I'll give it a try. You're pretty good at this.

CHOICE.Byrde: Wow, being praised by a pro! I don't know what to say!

text.Judge: Wh-What is it?

text.Phoenix: ... ( What... What's come over me...? Without thinking, I just blurted out, " Objection! "... And I yelled it at the top of my lungs, finger outstretched, ready to take on my opponent! What a rush! ) Detective Gumshoe!

text.Gumshoe: Y-You talking to me, pal?

text.Phoenix: Please state the defendant's name for me!

text.Payne: Objection!
What are you trying to prove with this futile exercise, Mr. Wright?

text.Phoenix: You'll see. This is a very crucial line of questioning! Actually, Mr. Payne, you can answer. The defendant's name, if you please.

text.Payne: Wh-Where is this ridiculous question coming from? The defendant's, uh, name is, uh... "Maggie Byrde".

text.Phoenix: I think someone needs to check the Court Record.

text.Payne: What...? It says right here that it's "Maggey Byrde". Aaaah!!

text.Phoenix: It looks like the bird caught the cat napping!

text.Judge: What's going on here!?

text.Gumshoe: I have no idea either, sir!

text.Phoenix: As you can see, the victim did indeed leave a name, " Maggie ". However, the defendant's name is actually spelled, " Maggey "! This is a blatant contradiction of facts!

text.Judge: Ohh!

text.Gumshoe: How about that? I hadn't even noticed!

text.Payne: Objection!
But, but, but...! But maybe the victim didn't know how to spell her name correctly...

text.Phoenix: Objection!
May I remind you that it was you who said, "The defendant is accused of killing her lover ." If they were truly lovers, it would be impossible for him to have not known her name!

text.Payne: Noooo!

text.Judge: This is very true. Mr. Payne.

text.Payne: Y-Yes, Your Honor?

text.Judge: Are you absolutely certain that the defendant and the victim, Dustin Prince, were, in fact, lovers?

text.Payne: Y-Yes, I am quite certain, Your Honor. They were a well-known couple in the police force.

text.Judge: Detective Gumshoe. Please testify for the court the relationship between the victim and the defendant.

text.Gumshoe: Yes, sir...

Officer Prince and Officer Byrde had been going out for about half a year. 
It sounded like they were even talking about marriage. 
The day of the incident just happened to be the victim's birthday, sir. 
Maggey... I mean Officer Byrde, had gotten Officer Prince a present. 
 It was something she had bought over 2 months ago. 
I should know, 'cause she came to me to ask what she should get for him.
text._info: (Changed from [It was something she had gotten over 2 months ago.] in the original release)

text.Judge: Oh... Those two sound like they were close...

text.Payne: Nevertheless, tragedy struck.

text.Judge: Hmm, yes, I see... You may cross-examine the witness, Mr. Wright.

text.Gumshoe: Officer Prince and Officer Byrde had been going out for about half a year.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
How do you know about this?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Every year in March, we have a training camp for us cops. Officer Byrde was a rookie at the time, and she and Officer Prince seemed to hit it off.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( They got close, I take it... )

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Actually, I was supposed to go, too, but... I couldn't pay the deposit for the trip, so I didn't. If only I had gone on that trip...

CHOICE.Judge: What is it?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Oh, uh, nothing, sir! Really! Anyway...

text.Gumshoe: It sounded like they were even talking about marriage.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Marriage? But wasn't the victim 8 years older than her?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: What!? You saying a guy's gotta marry someone the same age as himself, pal!?

CHOICE.Phoenix: No, that's not what I meant at all...

CHOICE.Byrde: Detective Gumshoe and Dustin were only a year apart, you know?

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Ugh... I think this fella has a ways to go before marriage... )

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Mind your own business, pal!

text.Gumshoe: The day of the incident just happened to be the victim's birthday, sir.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
The day of the incident... You mean September 6th?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yeah. The victim, Officer Prince, had just gotten off duty at 5:30 PM that day, and since Maggey's night shift hadn't started yet, they went to the park for a bit...

CHOICE.Judge: Ah, I remember when I was young and in love. Oh, it was a jolly time.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( That's great, Your Honor... I'm glad you're such a cheerful old man... )

text.Gumshoe: Maggey... I mean, Officer Byrde, had gotten Officer Prince a present.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
... You seem to know a lot about the defendant.

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Well, that's because, uh, I'm her boss. And I've gotta watch out for my subordinates!

CHOICE.Phoenix: But even what she was going to give as a present? Isn't that going a bit too far...?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Hey, pal! Watch what you say! I know everything that happens under me! If someone so much as scratches their...

Mr. Wright! Please refrain from badgering the witness!

CHOICE.Judge: I agree. Even if this witness has a crush on the defendant, that should not be the point of discussion at this time.

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Whoa! Wait a second! Why are we talking about this!? It's all YOUR fault, pal! You're guilty, guilty, guilty! I should have you arrested!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( I think the good Detective is about done here... )

Just now, I believe you said that the present was something she had " bought over 2 months ago ".

text.Byrde: Wh-What is it this time?

text.Phoenix: That testimony didn't sound like it had any contradictions in it to me. There just wasn't anything that really stuck out as odd.

text.Byrde: Yeah... I wonder what would happen if you tried to get more information from him?

text.Phoenix: Get more information?

text.Byrde: Yeah! You know! Like how they " press " people on those old cop shows, sir!

text.Phoenix: So I should try " pressing " him, huh?
( I don't know where this will lead me, but... ) Of course it is relevant! That glove is the key to this whole case!

text.Byrde: Yes! Bluffing to the max! Now, THIS is the Mr. Wright I know! I'm so happy you're back, sir! I was wondering how long it'd take! This is great!

text.Phoenix: ( Hmm, pressing people... It feels like I've done this before. As if I used to do this to squeeze information from even the most tight-lipped people. )

text.Judge: Very well. If you are that convinced, then let's hear some more about this matter.

text.Gumshoe: Actually, I brought the glove with me today.

text.Phoenix: And?

text.Judge: Why didn't you say so earlier? Hurry and show the glove to this court!

text.Gumshoe: Well, I didn't think it had anything to do with this case... Anyway, this is it, sir.

text.Judge: It's, uh... rather yellow, isn't it?

text.Gumshoe: Officer Prince really liked the color yellow.

text.Phoenix: And that's why you had to special order it?

text.Byrde: Yup, that's right! That, and one other reason...

text.Judge: I think this court has heard enough. It is clear that the victim and the defendant were involved with each other.

text.Payne: Yes, that's correct, Your Honor.

text.Judge: Now, if that is true, it brings up an important question. Was the name "Maggie" really written by the victim?

text.Payne: I see your point, Your Honor. Detective Gumshoe, please tell the court a little more about the name on the ground.

text.Gumshoe: Yes, sir.

We first looked into the handwriting. 
Unfortunately, we couldn't confirm that it was the victim's handwriting. 
Next, we checked the victim's pointer finger. 
We found out that there was sand trapped under the victim's fingernail. 
There were also scratches on the skin that were caused by him writing on the ground. 
From this, we could confirm that the victim wrote this name with his right hand.
text._info: (Changed from [We first looked into the handwriting, sir.] in the original release)

text.Judge: Hmm... Yes, a perfectly logical conclusion. Now then, Mr. Wright, you may cross-examine the witness.

text.Phoenix: Thank you, Your Honor.

text.Gumshoe: We first looked into the handwriting.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
But can you really determine handwriting based on a sample written in sand?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Heh, this is why amateurs are amateurs. We're not a buncha simpletons, pal! Scientific investigation in this country's actually pretty good.

CHOICE.Judge: Hmm, I believe it's time to get back to the real point.

CHOICE.Payne: Agreed, Your Honor. So, what was the result of the investigation?

text.Gumshoe: Unfortunately, we couldn't confirm that it was the victim's handwriting.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
So in the end, you couldn't confirm it?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Hey, don't you look down on us! I told you! We're not a bunch of simpletons, pal! Everyone knows you can't find out everything you want with scientific investigation!

CHOICE.Judge: I've never heard that before.

CHOICE.Payne: Me, either.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Nor I.

CHOICE.Byrde: I never heard anything like that at the police academy, sir...

CHOICE.Gumshoe: OK, so I made it up. Anyway...

text.Gumshoe: Next, we checked the victim's pointer finger.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
His pointer finger?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: You know, the one you're always POINTING and waving around in people's faces.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Aha, ha, ha. Don't tell me it bothers you...

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Every time you do it, I have a mini-heart attack. It's like you're trying to kill me, pal.

CHOICE.Payne: In any case, you examined the victim's index finger, correct?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yeah. We figured there should be something on his finger if he had been writing in sand.

CHOICE.Judge: Hmm... And the results?

text.Gumshoe: We found that there was sand trapped under the victim's fingernail.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
And what does that prove?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Well, it proves that he did write that name with his own finger.

CHOICE.Payne: Yes, which explains why there was sand stuck under his nail.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( I guess he's right... )

CHOICE.Gumshoe: And there's more...

text.Gumshoe: There were also scratches on the skin that were caused by him writing on the ground.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
"Scratches on his skin?"

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yup. You can't see them with your naked eye, but they're there.

CHOICE.Judge: That is incredible!

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Sure is! That's the power of scientific investigation! They're so small that we had to use a magnifying glass... like a really strong one. It's got that really scientific-sounding name...

CHOICE.Phoenix: You mean a microscope?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: Yeah, that's it! We used one of those and that's how we found them!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( I can't believe this guy doesn't know what a microscope is... )

text.Gumshoe: From this, we could confirm that the victim wrote this name with his right hand.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Are you absolutely sure?

CHOICE.Gumshoe: I believe in the power of science.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Hmm, I wonder if my evidence is solid enough to counter with? )
Objection!

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads to "Detective Gumshoe. Take a look at this."

text.Phoenix: ( Listening to this, you would think there was only one conclusion... that the name was definitely written by the victim... )

text.Byrde: But don't you think that would be really strange, sir!? If Dustin really wrote that message with his right hand, do you think I would have gone through that much trouble to get him his present?

text.Phoenix: ( The present ...? What about it...? )
Detective Gumshoe. Take a look at this.

text.Gumshoe: That's the glove, right?

text.Phoenix: Could you tell the court what is special about this glove?

text.Gumshoe: What's special? Um, never really thought about it, but uh... It's REALLY yellow... ... And that's about it.

text.Phoenix: Yes, it's REALLY yellow, but that is only one of its qualities.

text.Gumshoe: Huh?

text.Phoenix: There's another reason why it's special.

text.Judge: And what would that be?

text.Phoenix: It's very simple. This glove is made for a left-handed person!

text.Gumshoe: Left-handed...?

text.Judge: Why, you're absolutely right! This glove is made to be worn on the right hand !

text.Phoenix: That is why it had to be custom-made. I have never seen a bright yellow left-hander's glove for sale. Have you?

text.Gumshoe: Well, um... no.

text.Phoenix: So, Detective. Which hand did the victim use to write the name with, again...?

text.Gumshoe: That's easy! Look, it's obvious from this picture that it was his... W-W-Wait a sec...

text.Phoenix: Don't forget that the victim was left-handed !

text.Gumshoe: Aaaaah!!

text.Payne: Objection!
This is... This is... I mean... I... Objec--

text.Judge: Overruled. Mr. Wright, I would like to know what your line of reasoning proves.

text.Phoenix: There is only one conclusion that can be drawn! A left-handed person could not have written a message with his right hand! Therefore! The person who wrote the name " Maggie " could not have been the victim!

text.Judge: Order! Order! When you think about it that way, then yes, it is not possible that this name was written by the victim himself.

text.Gumshoe: Then that means Maggey is...!

text.Payne: No... IT'S NOT POSSIBLE!!

text.Judge: Mr. Payne.

text.Payne: Y-Y-Yes, Your Honor?

text.Judge: The evidence the prosecution has presented has failed to prove the defendant's guilt. In fact, I believe you have proven her to be innocent !

text.Payne: NOOOOOOO!

text.Byrde: Alright! You did it, Mr. Wright! Whew! I feel like I can breathe again!

text.Judge: It seems that we have reached the conclusion. You did a fine job once again, Mr. Wright.

text.Phoenix: Me, Your Honor? Ah, well, thank you, sir...

text.Byrde: See, you got complimented by the judge again! You're really good! And that's why you can't give up being a lawyer, sir!

text.Phoenix: ( Are you joking!? I'm more than ready to retire! )

text.Judge: I will now announce my verdict. This court finds the defendant, Maggey Byrde...

text.Payne: Objection!
No!! Not yet! I mean, please give me a few more minutes, Your Honor.

text.Judge: Wh-What is the meaning of this, Mr. Payne!?

text.Payne: The prosecution is not finished yet!

text.Phoenix: What do you mean!?

text.Payne: We would like to call our next witness to the stand!

text.Phoenix: Whaaaaaaaaaat!?

text.Judge: And what did this witness... witness?

text.Payne: The moment the victim was pushed to his death ! What's more, he saw the very face of the culprit !

text.Phoenix: What the heck!?

text.Judge: Order! Order in the court! I believe a recess is in order. Afterward, we will hear from this new witness.

text.Phoenix: ( I had a feeling that was a bit too easy... Hmm, I need more information. I'll have to see what I can find out during this recess. I can't let my guard down! It's only going to get tougher from here! )

text.Judge: Court is adjourned for recess!

text.ACTION: September 8, 11:43 AM District Court Defendant Lobby No. 1

text.Byrde: A-Amnesia!? I can't believe my lawyer's trying to defend me in such a state...
Why didn't you tell me, sir!?

text.Phoenix: I'm sorry I didn't mention it to you.

text.Byrde: Oh! I know what to do! I heard you can fix something like this with a really strong shock to your system! Come on, lower your head a little! A Maggey Kick should be all you need!

text.Phoenix: Ah, no, no, no. I think I'll pass on this one.

text.Byrde: Come on! ... I-I'm sorry. Whenever I see someone in trouble, I have a hard time leaving them alone... I tend to stick my nose where it doesn't belong and try to tackle everyone's problems.
text._info: (Changed from [Come on! ... Ah, I'm sorry.] in the original release)

text.Phoenix: ( Well, my head's one problem you won't be tackling today... ) Well, we're here to solve your problem first. We can deal with mine later. For now, do you think you can fill me in on a few things?

text.Byrde: Of course! I'd be honored to! Ah, well, I guess we'll start with my name and then I can tell you about me!

text.Phoenix: No, no, that's ok. Really. I think I know you and your name pretty well by now. I was wondering if you could help me figure out a few things about myself. So, my name is "Phoenix Wright"? What a weird name.

text.Byrde: Hmmmm... This is serious. You really don't remember. I'll tell you what, sir. You can have this back, and maybe it'll help!

text.Phoenix: ...? This is... a business card?

text.Byrde: I got this from you. It's my most prized possession! You can borrow it for now, but please give it back, OK!?

text.Phoenix: OK. ( There are some numbers written on the back... )

text.Byrde: Oh, that's your cell phone number!

text.Phoenix: I guess for now, we should stop talking about me, and start talking about this case.

text.Byrde: This case...?

text.Phoenix: Yup. Can you think of anything that would be helpful for me to know?

text.Byrde: Um, what can I tell you...? Ah, um... Hmm... I can't think of anything other than the incident with that cell phone, but...

text.Phoenix: ... Cell phone ?

text.Byrde: Yeah! Your eyes lit up when we talked about it at the Detention Center, sir!

text.Phoenix: ...! Hurry up then and tell me! This might be very important!

text.Byrde: OK! Roger! It was on the day of the crime, just before 6 PM... I picked up a lost cell phone while on a walk with Dustin.
All of a sudden, the phone began to ring...
"Um, hello?"

text.???: "Oh, thank you! I've been searching for my phone."

text.Byrde: "Is this yours? Oh, I'm glad you called! We can meet up and I can give this back!"

text.???: "I'll be right there, um... I'm sorry, I didn't catch your name..."

text.Byrde: "You can call me Maggey!"
We agreed to meet up at 6 PM. Dustin and I waited for the person to show up... but they never did.

text.Phoenix: Hmmmm... So where is the phone you found now?

text.Byrde: I gave it to you yesterday!

text.Phoenix: Huh? To me? ( Is it that phone in my pocket...? ) Y-You mean this?

text.Byrde: Do you think it has anything to do with the murder?

text.Phoenix: I... don't really know... But if my eyes "lit up"...

text.???: AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHH!! YOU WERE HERE ALL ALONG!! You're so mean!! I called you a million times but you wouldn't pick up! And when I went to check in the courtroom, everyone had already left...

text.Phoenix: ( Ack! Now who in the heck is this? Let me guess. I'm supposed to know this girl too... )

text.???: Hey, good morning, Maggey!

text.Byrde: And a good morning to you, too, Maya!

text.Maya: So!? So!? How's it going!?

text.Byrde: Is there a word for "worse than abysmal"...?

text.Maya: Oh? And what if I said that everything will be fine? That's right! It's Maya to the rescue with the ultra-decisive super-important evidence! Here you are, Nick! The thing you wanted me to bring!

text.Phoenix: Huh? Oh, ah, thanks... ( What the heck is this? A list? It has about 20 people's names and phone numbers written on it. )

text.Maya: It was kind of tough, but I managed to dig up some dirt! It looks like these guys are up to no good.
text._info: (Changed from [It was kind of tough, but I managed to find out some dirt!] in the original release)

text.Phoenix: "No good"? As in?

text.Maya: There's a group of con artists the police are currently investigating. I think these guys are members of that group.

text.Phoenix: Why would a group of con artists pop up in a case like this?

text.Maya: Don't look at me!

text.Phoenix: Hmm... And where did you get this list from in the first place?

text.Maya: Whaaaaat!? Don't you remember, Nick!? You're the one who asked me to look this up yesterday!
text._info: (Changed from [Whaaaaat!? Why are you asking that!?] in the original release)

text.Phoenix: Oh... is that right?

text.Maya: These numbers were in the memory of that phone Maggey found.

text.Phoenix: Hmm, so that's where they're from.

text.Maya: You're awfully forgetful these days, Nick. I hope I never get to be a forgetful old prune like you!

text.Byrde: Um, Maya... Actually, Mr. Wright is...

text.Bailiff: Mr. Wright! Recess is now over. Please bring the defendant and return to the courtroom immediately!

text.Maya: Oh, oops! Guess you have to get going! We can talk about you being old later, Nick!

text.Byrde: W-Wish us luck!

text.Phoenix: ( I guess I have all the pieces now... More or less. All that's left is to put it all together. I'm not going to lose this. I can't! )

text.Maya: Come on, Nick. Better get a move on!

text.Phoenix: Y-Yeah.

text.ACTION: September 8, 11:54 AM District Court Courtroom No. 2

text.Judge: The court will now reconvene. Please call your next witness to the stand, Mr. Payne.

text.Payne: Yes, Your Honor. But before I do, if I may say a few words...

text.Judge: What is it, Mr. Payne?

text.Payne: It's about the next witness. He has a tendency to say things that rub people the wrong way, you see, so I ask that the court might be a little lenient on...

text.Judge: There is no need to give a preface. Just hurry up and call your witness, please.

text.Payne: Y-Yes, Your Honor. ...The prosecution calls its next witness: a drifter who was taking a walk in the park on the day of the murder!
Please state your name for the court, witness.

text.???: Before I do, I'd like to clarify a little something.

text.Payne: Huh? Oh, alright, go ahead.

text.???: Just now, you introduced my wonderful self to the court, correct? Perhaps as a "drifter who was taking a walk "?

text.Payne: D-Did I?

text.???: But I will not stand for that! Now you've tinted the court's eyes and colored me wrongly. Sure, I suppose calling me a university student would not be the absolute truth, but to give in and just settle would be as evil as death and I can't have that! Everything in my life is to be of the utmost, highest, top grade quality , you understand. I am merely looking for that perfect, top notch, unbeatable university , don't you see...? I have a rigorous selection process and I was in serious thought during my " walk " as...

text.Payne: Yes, yes, I understand. I'm very sorry. I will be more careful from now on.

text.Maya: Wh-What is he? A human chatterbox?

text.Phoenix: Ugh... I have to question HIM?

text.???: Fashion! Cars! Women! Glasses! And of course, University! First-rates only need apply!

text.Phoenix: ( Glasses...? But you aren't wearing glasses... )

text.Judge: That's enough! Your name, witness.

text.???: Oh? Is that how you want to play this? Using your power and influence to keep the young people down. I see how you work now. You old people and your dirty tricks. You thought you had me, but you thought wrong.

text.Judge: I-I'm sorry. It won't happen again.

text.Phoenix: ( Oh man... )

text.Wellington: I forgive you. Alright, I suppose I can tell you my name. I am Richard Wellington, the "Drifting Virtuoso" with a Ph.D. in Drifting, as it were. If you wanted to, you could call me a "University Student in Transit".

text.Payne: Ahem, Mr. Wellington. On the day of the murder, you were taking a... er, strolling through the park, correct?

text.Wellington: It would appear that you are attached to that word. If you must, then by all means. But I remind you that I am in no way a prepubescent boy, "out on a walk" with mommy. If you must know, I am--

text.Payne: Anyway! Please testify to this court what you saw during your walk through the park!

text.Wellington: See, you said it again! " Taking a walk "... You know, you--

text.Judge: What you witnessed will do, Mr. Wellington!

text.Wellington:
I was at the park all afternoon, deep in thought about my life situation. 
I don't remember the time all that well, but I do believe it was past 6 PM. 
All of a sudden, a police officer falls from above, right in front of my eyes. 
Without a thought, I looked up, and there I met the eyes of a charming, young lady. 
Of course I remember her sweet face. It was that of the pretty defendant there. 
The only other thing I saw was the banana that fell with the police officer.

text.Judge: Hmm, that was certainly a decisive testimony.

text.Maya: Decisive!? Nick, did you hear what he just said!?

text.Phoenix: Yeah.

text.Maya: That's all you have to say? How can you be so calm!?

text.Phoenix: ( It's strange... My mind is very calm and clear. ) Maybe it's because I... believe in my client .

text.Maya: You mean Maggey?

text.Phoenix: Yes. And if she really is innocent, then that can only mean one thing: That guy is lying!

text.Judge: You may now question the witness, Mr. Wright.

text.Phoenix: ( I'll find out the truth, no matter how well you craft your lies! )

text.Wellington: I was at the park all afternoon, deep in thought about my life situation.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
So you were at the park all afternoon? You seem to have a lot of free time.

CHOICE.Wellington: Hmph. That was very rude of you. But then again, what can I expect? That's what you get from a man who graduated from a no-name, trashy university.

CHOICE.Phoenix: N-No name? Trashy...?

CHOICE.Wellington: Now, this might be hard for a mush-headed, feeble-minded baboon like you, but I have to think very carefully about the future of our great country.

CHOICE.Phoenix: But I thought you said you were thinking about which college to go to just now...

CHOICE.Wellington: Oh, puh-leaze. Which university I go to will directly affect the very future of this country!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( That arrogant little snot... )

text.Wellington: I don't remember the time all that well, but I do believe it was past 6 PM.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
How did you know what time it was? I see you're not wearing a watch, so...

CHOICE.Wellington: Is that the best you can do? Do you think you can discredit me like that? You're just a third-rate, biased fool. I guess I can't expect real smarts from you.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Grr... His arrogance is really intolerable... So, what should I do now...? )
Answer the question! How did you know what time it was!?

CHOICE.Wellington: Tsk, tsk. I can't believe I have to deal with a worm like you. You're just a shallow man who can only slam on desks and point at people for fun. Hmph, I guess I don't have a choice. I'll try to explain it so that even a third-rate simpleton like you can understand. There was this little thing they call a " clock " at the park. Did you get that? Do you know what a clock is? It's a thing that tells you the time.

CHOICE.Payne: As you can see, Mr. Wright, it's even in this picture of the crime scene.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Oh... So it is... Urk. )

CHOICE.Wellington: I looked at that clock, and that's how I knew the time. But if you ask me, this whole concept of breaking time apart into fragments... It's total and utter nonsense that no man should follow. A real first-class person doesn't live by, nor is he chained by, time. And to wear a watch? Hah! What a ridiculous notion ! People should live freely without constraints. That's how life should be!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( And yet again, another flood of meaningless words... Talk about a first-class waste of time... )

CHOICE.Wellington: In any case...

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Well, I guess there's no point in pressing him further. After all, there was a clock right there at the crime scene... )

text.Wellington: All of a sudden, a police officer falls from above, right in front of my eyes.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
And how did you know he was a police officer?

CHOICE.Wellington: You obviously have no idea how powerful my deductive reasoning skills are. With one glance, I could tell just what kind of occupation he held. That shoddy, do-it-yourself hairstyle practically screamed "I'm a police officer" . It was also the way he tied his tie and those cheap, low-quality shoes. Ugh. Oh, and I suppose it was also because he was wearing an officer's uniform .

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Shouldn't that statement have come first!? )

CHOICE.Maya: Wow, that's pretty impressive. Hey, Nick! Do you think he's figured out what I do?

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Even I haven't figured that out yet... )

text.Wellington: Without a thought, I looked up, and there I met the eyes of a charming, young lady.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
Are you sure you got a good look at her face?

CHOICE.Wellington: Animals have this thing called an "eye", Mr. Wright. They use this "eye" to see things. In the case of humans, we have two of them. Yes, even you!

CHOICE.Phoenix: I don't care if I have them or not! Did you or did you not get a clear look at her face!?

CHOICE.Payne: Objection!
That's what the witness was just about to get to. I would like to request that Mr. Wright not use such a loud voice during questioning.

CHOICE.Judge: Sustained. Mr. Wright, please refrain from raising your voice in this court.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Then please don't make me have to raise my voice. )

CHOICE.Wellington: Are you finished? I'd like to continue, if that's alright with you.

text.Wellington: Of course I remember her sweet face. It was that of the pretty defendant there.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
So you're SURE you are not mistaken?

CHOICE.Wellington: Please. Don't confuse your pitiful, train-wreck of a life with mine. I'm what you call a famous brand-name product, while you are only a cheap imitation. There is no way someone as magnificent as myself could have made a mistake.

CHOICE.Payne: Of course, of course.

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Oh ho ho ho. Of course. )

CHOICE.Judge: Did you notice anything else of interest, witness?

text.Wellington: The only other thing I saw was the banana that fell with the police officer.

CHOICE.Phoenix: HOLD IT!
The banana...?

CHOICE.Wellington: Well, it was actually more than just one. More like a bunch of bananas.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Now what would a bunch of bananas be doing there...?

CHOICE.Wellington: And why would I know such a thing? I'm only telling you what I saw.

CHOICE.Maya: That's really strange. Maggey never mentioned anything about a bunch of bananas. That's it, Nick! He's gotta be lying about the bananas!

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( Hmm... He could be, but... there's no reason for him to lie about there being bananas at the crime scene . ) And what if it's not a lie?

CHOICE.Maya: Well, maybe he thought he was seeing one thing, and it was something else...?

CHOICE.Phoenix: ( If he mistook something else for a bunch of bananas, then that would be an inaccuracy . Think Phoenix, think! )
Objection!

text.Phoenix: ( If my client is innocent, there is no way he could've seen what he says he did. )

text.Maya: Which means if we can somehow show he's lying...

text.Phoenix: Yeah, that's exactly what we need do. ( She's right. She's got a sharp mind, but I just wish I could remember who she is... )

text.Maya: Is everything OK, Nick...?

text.Phoenix: Mr. Wellington. I believe I have the bananas you saw... right here!

text.Wellington: Ah, so you knew about the bananas, too. Why didn't you say so earlier? But don't think you can use this as a way to pull more information out of me.

text.Phoenix: ( And that's where you'd be wrong. )

text.Judge: M-Mr. Wright. What is the meaning of this?

text.Payne: Isn't that the baseball glove?

text.Wellington: Huh!? Wh-Wh-What!? A baseball glove??

text.Phoenix: Doesn't it look delicious? Care for a bite?

text.Wellington: Th-That's... That's not... It's a... Noooooooo!

text.Phoenix: Your Honor! I think this proves one very important fact! This witness...

CHOICE.Phoenix: Mr. Wellington loves large bananas !

CHOICE.Maya: Uh, Nick... I hope you've noticed the icy glares we're getting from everyone in here!

CHOICE.Judge: Wh-What in the world do you mean?

CHOICE.Wellington: I'll have you know I like strawberries much better than bananas.

CHOICE.Phoenix: Whoops...

CHOICE.Judge: Think it over one more time and try again, Mr. Wright.

CHOICE.ACTION: Leads to "By the way, just how bad are your eyes?"
USER SELECTS knows nothing about baseball

CHOICE.Phoenix: Mr. Wellington has never played baseball! That would explain why he didn't even know what a glove is!

CHOICE.Maya: Uh, Nick... I hope you've noticed the icy glares we're getting from everyone in here!

CHOICE.Judge: Wh-What in the world do you mean?

CHOICE.Wellington: When I was in junior high, I was a star pitcher... Well, 4th in line, actually, but...

CHOICE.Phoenix: Whoops...

CHOICE.Judge: Think it over one more time and try again, Mr. Wright.

text.Phoenix: By the way, just how bad are your eyes?

text.Wellington: Huh? How... What... You... Why are you asking me about this all of a sudden!?

text.Payne: Objection!
Your Honor, it is very simple to mistake a glove for a bunch of bananas...
